Eanes Independent School District Academics grade: A+ Culture & Diversity grade: B- Survey overall experience rating: 4.1 out of 5.0 Photo: Karen Warren, Houston Chronicle Image 33 of 33 Report: Texas school district explores using students as janitors in cost-cutting measure 1 / 33 Back to Gallery A budget shortfall brought on by a cut of state funding has lead the Frisco Independent School District to explore some creative ways to save money over the coming years.
One of the cost-cutting proposals reportedly includes having students empty trash cans in order to cut back on janitorial staff, according to the Dallas Morning News . Whether or not students would be tasked with other janitorial duties was not reported.
TRAVIS COUNTY LIVING: The best school district in Texas is also ridiculously wealthy
High school students may also have to pay additional fees to participate in athletics. According to the Dallas Morning News the pay-to-play scenario could see students paying up to $200 to play high school sports.
Another plan has volunteers acting as library aides instead of paying for paid staffers.
Last year Frisco ISD lost $30 million in state funding after the end of a fund called Additional State Aid for Tax Reduction. A proposed property tax hike in the area was struck down by voters.
Houston Chronicle sports writers Angel Verdejo and Adam Coleman discuss the Texas High School Football 2016 season highlights and low points.
Media: MediaOS Video These ideas and others came from a set of recommendations from community members and school district officials in a recent brainstorming sessions and focus groups.
PASS AND FAIL: Texas issues letter grades to Houston-area schools, districts
It appears, according to the Star-Telegram report, that everyone agrees that extracurricular activities aren't in danger, but that pay-to-play might make more sense for the district. Additional student fees could also be added for club activities and travel, two expensive pieces of the equation.
The openings of at least four new schools has been delayed to cut additional costs.
Frisco ISD is one of the fastest-growing districts in the state of Texas.
